abstract.p: Letter from Thomas Ansel says affirmative action may be vindicated, but there are also negative effects on those who are passed over in favor of minorities or women

block.p: The report on affirmative action to which Michael M. Weinstein refers (Editorial Observer, Oct. 17) is only reassuring if one agrees with the premise that an increase in the numbers of minorities or women in the work force with little negative workplace effect constitutes success.

The report on affirmative action to which Michael M. Weinstein refers (Editorial Observer, Oct. 17) is only reassuring if one agrees with the premise that an increase in the numbers of minorities or women in the work force with little negative workplace effect constitutes success.

The negative effect on those who are passed over in favor of minorities or women, the resentment toward an entire race and the impression (valid or not) that minority hirees are less qualified are also effects of affirmative action.
Our aim should not be just getting the numbers in balance, because the numbers are only the symptom of the problem.
